questions.text: A child is found to have paralysis due to poliovirus infection. Which of the following is false regarding the paralysis seen?

choices.text: It is an upper motor neuron type
Strenuous physical exercise during the onset exaggerates the paralysis
It can be caused by polio vaccination

questions.solution:
Poliovirus mainly affects the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and medulla oblongata (cranial nerve nuclei), causing lower motor neuron (LMN) type of paralysis. It damages motor and autonomic nerves; sensory nerves are not involved.

Poliovirus is a non-enveloped, positive-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Picornaviridae family. Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) are known. Ages 6 months to 5 years are most commonly affected. The virus is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and has an incubation period of 8-12 days. Humans are the only known reservoir for the polioviruses.

The virus colonizes and replicates in the GI mucosa (M cells), followed by entry into the blood via regional lymph nodes. In blood, it causes viremia and gets access to the CNS via the peripheral nerves, finally reaching the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. 

Most cases are subclinical. Some have minor illnesses like fever, sore throat, headache, and malaise. It can present as non-paralytic polio (aseptic meningitis) or paralytic polio (flaccid paralysis with absent deep tendon reflexes). Most frequently, the completely affected muscle is the tibialis anterior. It is asymmetric paralysis which is more severe if strenuous physical exercise occurred during the onset of paralysis. Death usually occurs due to respiratory paralysis.

Vaccination schedule for polio:

  • Live attenuated: oral polio vaccine (OPV) (Sabin) at birth (day 0); then boosters at 6, 10, and 14 weeks and at 15-18 months; additional doses till 5 years
  • Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) (Salk) given intradermally; two fractional doses at 6 and 14 weeks as well as 9 months of age.

questions.text: An outbreak of paralytic polio has occurred in Nigeria. Which of the following is the most likely type to cause such outbreaks?
questions.solution:
Most of the outbreaks of paralytic polio are caused by the type 1 virus.

Three antigenically distinct serotypes (types 1, 2, and 3) of poliovirus are known. Poliovirus type 1 has historically been the predominant cause of poliomyelitis worldwide and continues to be transmitted in endemic areas.

Most infections with poliovirus are asymptomatic. Rarely, patients can have the following presentations:

  • Abortive poliomyelitis - a minor illness, manifested by fever, malaise, sore throat, or headache.
  • Non-paralytic poliomyelitis - manifested by aseptic meningitis.
  • Paralytic poliomyelitis - aseptic meningitis followed by severe back, neck, and muscle pain with rapid/gradual onset of motor weakness. It is the least common presentation of poliovirus infection.

Wild poliovirus type 2 was eradicated in 1999. Until 2015, over 90% of cVDPV (circulating vaccine-derived polioviruses) cases were due to the type 2 component in OPV.

Bivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) contains serotypes 1 and 3. Serotype 2 has been removed, as it is implicated in the pathogenesis of cVDPV and occasionally vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP).

Note:

On 25 April 2016, India switched from trivalent oral polio vaccine (OPV) to bivalent OPV; this day is called the National switch day.

questions.text: Which of the following signs may be seen in a child with polio?
questions.solution:
All of the above signs may be seen in a child suffering from polio. 

  • Tripod sign - When the child is asked to sit up unassisted, the child assumes the tripod posture.
  • Kiss the knee sign - The child cannot kiss the knee due to spine stiffness.
  • Head drop sign - A hand is placed under the patient's shoulder and the trunk is raised. Usually, the head will also raise, but in the case of poliomyelitis, the head drops backward.

questions.text: You have been appointed as a member of the acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance team. What age groups would you target for surveillance?
questions.solution:
Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance is done in children from 0-15 years.

Every case of acute flaccid paralysis in any child under 15 years is to be reported promptly. Fecal samples of all these cases are obtained (2 samples) and transported to the laboratory within 72 hours of collection at 4–8 degree Celcius or frozen at -20 degree Celcius. This process is known as the reverse cold chain.

The differential diagnosis for acute flaccid paralysis include the following:

  • Non-polio enteroviruses
  • West Nile virus
  • Guillan–Barre syndrome
  • Other neurotropic viruses: rabies, varicella-zoster, and Japanese encephalitis

questions.text: When was India declared polio-free by WHO?
questions.solution:
India was certified polio-free on March 27, 2014.

  • The last case of polio reported in India was in January 2011.
  • Type 2 virus was declared eradicated in September 2015.
  • Switch from trivalent to bivalent vaccine was done in India in April 2016.

World polio day is commemorated on October 24th of every year to raise awareness about the disease and eradicate polio. On World Polio Day 2019, the Type 3 virus was declared to be eradicated worldwide.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023 by WHO?

choices.text: Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection
Separation of polio surveillance and vaccine preventable disease surveillance
Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)

questions.solution:
Integration, not separation, of polio surveillance with vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) surveillance, is a part of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023.

Goals of the Polio Endgame Strategy 2019–2023

Goal One: Eradication

  • Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)
  • Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection and eliminate the risk of emergence of future VDPVs

Goal two: Integration

  • Contribute to strengthening immunization and health systems to help achieve and sustain polio eradication
  • Ensure sensitive poliovirus surveillance through integration with comprehensive vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) and communicable disease surveillance systems
  • Prepare for and respond to future outbreaks and emergencies

Goal Three: Certification & Containment

  • Certify eradication of WPV
  • Contain all polioviruses

questions.text: At your vaccination center, you have noticed increased reporting of vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP). Which of the following statement is true regarding this adverse effect of the vaccine?

choices.text: It occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine
It is more likely to occur if the first dose was parenteral inactivated polio vaccine
It Is most likely to occur if given on the same day as yellow fever vaccine
It is more likely to occur if multiple parenteral injections have been given at the same time

questions.solution:
Vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine (OPV).

VAPP is said to occur if:

  • Acute flaccid paralysis occurred 4 to 40 days after receiving OPV, and residual weakness lasted for more than 60 days after the onset of paralysis.
  • Isolation of vaccine-related poliovirus in any stool samples and no isolation of wild poliovirus from any stool samples.

Note:

  • VAPP: Vaccine-associated paralytic polio
  • VDPV: Vaccine-derived polio virus.  A very rare strain of polio virus, genetically changed from the original strain contained in OPV. 
  • cVDPV: circulating vaccine-derived polio virus. In areas of low vaccination coverage, a VDPV strain may revert to a form that can cause cases of paralytic polio, leading to an outbreak. This form is called a cVDPV.

questions.text: While volunteering in an orphanage that takes care of disabled kids, you notice the typical hand-knee gait of polio in a child. He walks by putting his right hand on his right lower thigh while stepping forward. Which of the following muscle weakness is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Polio commonly affects the quadriceps, and weakness of the quadriceps leads to the buckling (bending) of the knee while walking or bearing weight on the leg. So, in order to walk, the person has to prevent the buckling of the knee by supporting with the hand, producing a hand-knee gait.

Examination findings in paralytic polio:

A. In the early stage

  • Asymmetric motor paralysis - involvement of affected muscles is haphazard. No associated sensory loss.
  • Commonly affects the lower limbs
  • Most common muscle affected - Quadriceps, although it is most often partially paralyzed
  • Most common muscle to undergo complete paralysis - Tibialis anterior
  • The most affected muscle in the hand - Opponens pollicis
  • Bulbar/bulbospinal polio - It is a rare but life-threatening disease affecting the motor neurons of the medulla and resulting in the involvement of the respiratory and cardiovascular centers, which may cause death.

B. In the late-stage

  • Weakness, wasting, and deformity of the limbs
  • At the hip-flexion-abduction-external rotation
  • At the knee, flexion deformity is common; in severe cases, there is triple deformity: flexion, posterior subluxation, and external rotation
  • At the foot, the commonest deformity is equino-varus. Other deformities - equinovalgus, calcaneo-valgus, and calcaneo-varus
  • In the upper limb: affects the shoulder and elbow, hand muscles are spared.

questions.text: Serological testing of a neonate born to an HIV-infected mother turned out positive. Which of the following is the most likely route by which the newborn might have acquired the infection?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of HIV infection in an infant is the intrapartum transmission.

The mechanism of intrapartum transmission appears to be mucosal exposure to infected blood and cervicovaginal secretions in the birth canal. The intrauterine contractions during active labor/delivery could also increase the risk of late microtransfusions.

Routes of HIV transmission in an infant:

  • Intrauterine
  • Intrapartum - most common
  • Breastfeeding - least common

Risk factors for vertical transmission:

  • High maternal viremia (most important)
  • Preterm delivery (<34 weeks)
  • Vitamin A deficiency
  • Prolonged rupture of membranes (>4 hours)
  • Low birth weight
  • Low maternal CD4 count

questions.text: You are evaluating children infected with HIV in a village, where there is little awareness about HIV and its treatment. Which of the following will be the most common presenting feature in these children?
questions.solution:
Failure to thrive is the universal finding in children with HIV.

Important features in HIV-infected children include the following:

  • Presenting features - failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, oral thrush, chronic diarrhea, or respiratory symptoms.
  • Most common AIDS-defining illness (opportunistic infection) in children - Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia
  • Most common fungal infection - oral candidiasis
  • Recurrent and chronic bacterial infections (especially, Streptococcus pneumoniae)
  • Most common GI disease - chronic/recurrent diarrhea with malabsorption
  • Most common renal disease - nephrotic syndrome
  • Most common hematological manifestation - anemia
  • Most common neoplasms - non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, primary CNS lymphoma, and leiomyosarcomas

questions.text:
Match the following HIV cases with their respective stages.
Clinical case Stage
1. A 5-year old child with persistent diarrhea for 20 days. a. Stage 3
2. An asymptomatic 2-year-old with persistent generalized lymphadenopathy. b. Stage 4
3. A 7-year-old with recurrent oral ulcers and persistent parotid enlargement c. Stage 1
4. A 4-year-old with HIV-associated cardiomyopathy d. Stage 2
questions.solution:
Correct match is: 1-a, 2-c, 3-d, 4-b.

A 5-year old child with persistent diarrhea for 20 days - Stage 3

An asymptomatic 2-year-old with persistent generalized lymphadenopathy - Stage 1

A 7-year-old with recurrent oral ulcers and persistent parotid enlargement - Stage 2

A 4-year-old with HIV-associated cardiomyopathy - Stage 4

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

Neurological-

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in labor comes to the emergency department at 37 weeks gestation. She never had a prenatal checkup. The routine screening revealed she is HIV-positive. Which of the following method is least likely to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV?

choices.text: Administration of ART prophylaxis to baby after birth

questions.solution:
Vaginal cleansing before delivery is least likely to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV.

Methods to prevent perinatal transmission of HIV include the following:

  • Antiretroviral therapy (ART):
    • Single-dose nevirapine at the onset of labor followed by a single dose to the newborn within 72 hours of birth.
    • Zidovudine can also be used from the 2nd trimester onwards throughout pregnancy and for 6 weeks after birth to infancy.
    • Breastfed infants should receive NVP for 6 weeks if the mother is receiving cART, or NVP for the duration of breastfeeding if the mother is not on therapy. Formula-fed infants in resource-limited countries should receive ZDV bid or NVP qd for 6 weeks.
  • Elective cesarean section*
  • Breastfeeding: Usually contraindicated, except in developing countries where breastfeeding may be continued for 6 months.

*Note: 

Maternal cART is documented to decrease the rate of perinatal HIV-1 transmission to <2%, and <1% if the mother’s viral RNA level is <1,000 copies/mL at delivery. Thus, elective C-section at 38 weeks of gestation should be considered only for women whose viral load is >1,000 copies/ mL in late gestation, to further reduce the risk of vertical transmission.

Guidelines for the use of antiretroviral drugs during C-section are as follows:

  • For elective (planned) C-section, ART should be given prior to the operation.
  • Women on lifelong ART should continue their standard ART regimen.
  • In case of emergency C-section in pregnant women who are not on ART, the three-drug regimen should be started before the surgery and continued thereafter.

Related Pearl: Infant nevirapine (NVP) prophylaxis

Duration: Up to a minimum of 6 weeks. It can be extended to 12 weeks if the duration of ART in pregnant mother falls short of 4 weeks during pregnancy or if the mother is not already on ART during labour.

questions.text: A patient is started on HAART treatment for HIV. Her CD4 count is 150 cells/μl. She developed a fever and her symptoms worsened during her first week of treatment. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) is characterized by an increased inflammatory response to subclinical opportunistic infections after initiating retroviral therapy.

Features seen are fever, worsening of opportunistic infections, new manifestations like lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltrates. It typically occurs within 1st few weeks of starting therapy. It commonly occurs in patients with progressive disease, or severe CD4 + T-lymphocyte depletion.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication to start ART in children, as per the WHO guidelines?

choices.text: <11 months infant of CD4 count < 1500 cells/mm3

questions.solution:
Antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be initiated in all children with HIV, regardless of clinical stage or CD4 cell count, as per the latest WHO recommendations 2016.

Also, cotrimoxazole prophylaxis is recommended for infants, children, and adolescents with HIV, irrespective of their clinical and immune conditions.

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-week old infant to your PHC for immunization. The baby was not administered the BCG vaccine as he is HIV positive. His recent CD4 counts were 13%. Which of the following vaccines should you not administer in this child?
questions.solution:
The live attenuated oral polio vaccine (OPV) should be avoided in severely immunocompromised infants (CD4 cell percentage <15%) because of an increased risk of paralytic polio.

Vaccine Recommendation
Oral polio vaccine (OPV)

Yes, if CD4% ≥15%
No, if CD4% <15%
Varicella and MMR

Yes, if CD4% ≥15%
No, if CD4% <15%
Pentavalent (Hep B, DPT, Hib) Yes
Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) Yes
BCG No
Live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV or nasal spray) No
Injectable influenza vaccine (flu shot) Yes

NACO guidelines state that in general, all inactivated vaccines can be administered safely in HIV positive infants, while live attenuated vaccines are contraindicated in severely immuno-compromised infants and children (CD4 <15 %).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the 2025 HIV targets of Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026?

choices.text: 95% of women of reproductive age have their HIV and sexual and reproductive health service needs met.
90% of people living with HIV recieve preventive treatment for TB
95% of pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV have suppressed viral loads.
75% of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation of breastfeeding

questions.solution:
95%(not 75%) of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation of breastfeeding is part of the High level 2025 targets of Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026

High-level 2025 targets

  • 95% of people at risk of HIV infection have access to and use appropriate, prioritized, person-centered, and effective combination prevention options.
  • 95% of women of reproductive age have their HIV and sexual and reproductive health service needs met.
  • 95% of pregnant and breastfeeding women living with HIV have suppressed viral loads.
  • 95% of HIV-exposed children are tested by two months of age and again after cessation of breastfeeding
  • 75% of all children living with HIV have suppressed viral loads by 2023 (interim target)
  • 95–95–95 testing and treatment targets are achieved within all subpopulations, age groups, and geographic settings, including children living with HIV.
  • 90% of people living with HIV receive preventive treatment for TB.
  • 90% of people living with HIV and people at risk are linked to people-centered and context-specific integrated services for other communicable diseases, noncommunicable diseases, sexual health and gender-based violence, mental health, drug and substance use, and other services they need for their overall health and wellbeing.

The Strategy keeps people at the center and aims to unite countries, communities, and partners across and beyond the HIV response to take prioritized actions to accelerate progress towards the vision of zero new HIV infections, zero discrimination, and zero AIDS-related deaths.

This Strategy lays out a framework for transformative action to reduce the inequalities by 2025 and to get every country and every community on track to end AIDS by 2030.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant labourer who is HIV-positive delivers a healthy male baby. She was advised ART previously but has been non-compliant with her treatment. What is recommended by NACO with regards to feeding the baby?
questions.solution:
NACO recommends exclusive breastfeeding as the infant feeding choice in the first 6 months. This is irrespective of the fact that the mother is on ART or the infant is provided with ARV prophylaxis for 6 weeks.

Breast-feeding and replacement feed simultaneously (mixed feeds) in the first 6 months should not be done, as it leads to mucosal abrasions in the gut of the baby, thereby facilitating HIV entry.

Breast-feeding should not be stopped abruptly. Only in situations where breastfeeding cannot be done (maternal death, severe maternal illness) or individual mother’s choice (at her own risk), then exclusive replacement feeding which is safe, sustainable, affordable and feasible can be started.

In resource-rich settings/developed countries, exclusive alternative formulations are recommended.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the postnatal ward of a hospital. You receive an HIV-positive patient on PND-1. Which of the following tests would you use to detect HIV in the baby?
questions.solution:
HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother is diagnosed using HIV DNA PCR.

NACO recommends the use of a qualitative HIV-1 DNA PCR (NAT) in children aged <18months

Antibody assays (e.g., ELISA) that are commonly used for HIV testing in adults and older children are not reliable in infants and young children because of the persistence of transplacentally acquired maternal antibodies until 18 months after birth. For this reason, HIV virologic testing (PCR) must be performed using tests that detect HIV DNA or RNA. Scheduled repeated testing is necessary because test sensitivity increases with time from HIV virus exposure. Also, a very recent infection will not be detectable by PCR.

Cord blood should not be used for testing because of the possibility of contamination of the sample with maternal blood.

questions.text: The image given below depicts the mode of infection with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows, infection through fecal oral route, colonization of the organism, and replication in the GI mucosa (M cells), followed by entry into blood via regional lymph nodes. In blood, it causes viremia and gets access to the CNS via the peripheral nerves, finally reaching the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. The pathogenesis expalined above is that of polio infection.

Option A: Infection with Campylobacter jejuni is implicated in the pathogenesis of Guillain–Barre syndrome, where the antibodies against C. jejuni cross-react with the gangliosides (GM1) in the peripheral nervous system.

Option B: Hepatitis A infection occurs through the fecal-oral route, and the virus replicates in the GI mucosa and is then transported to the liver.

Option D: Rotavirus causes diarrhea by causing malabsorption.

questions.text: Kenny packs are used in the treatment of ________
questions.solution:
Kenny packs are used in the treatment of poliomyelitis.

Treatment of poliomyelitis includes the following:

  • Symptomatic and supportive treatment: Analgesics, bed rest, and physiotherapy
  • Sister Kenny’s treatment: Hot moist packs applied to muscles to relieve pain and spasm
  • Optimum positioning of limbs to prevent deformity
  • Management of pure bulbar poliomyelitis consists of maintaining the airway and avoiding the risk of aspiration.
